newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong to issue gold coins to mark 1997 handover.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong to issue gold coins to mark 1997 handover.

text.p: Hong Kong said on Wednesday it would issue a limited edition of commemorative gold coins next July to mark the British colony's return to Chinese rule.

The 1997 commemoratives would bear Hong Kong's floral emblem, the ubiquitous tree orchid, or purple bauhinia flower, on the obverse, with a design of the territory's skyline on the reverse, the government said in a statement.
The 22-carat gold coins would have a face value of HK$1,000 (US$128) and would be sold by inviting public applications, and, if too many orders came in, by drawing lots, the statement said.
"Making it legal tender adds appreciably to its attractiveness and value in the eyes of the collectors," it said.
The government did not say how many coins would be minted.
Hong Kong becomes an autonomous Special Administrative Region of China on July 1, 1997, under a "one country two systems" policy aimed at reintegrating lost Chinese territories.
China's central bank intends to issue its third set of Hong Kong-related commemorative coins on the date of the handover.
